title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
The White House has hit back at criticism from Wall Street and Silicon Valley at its plans to increase taxes for high-earning Americans, with a senior official saying it would affect the income of only 0.3 per cent of people filing taxes.

Joe Biden is this week expected to roll out a series of tax increases on the wealthy, including a near-doubling of levies on capital gains and dividends, in order to fund a new education and childcare spending package that could top $1.5tn.

“There's increasing evidence that over recent years in fact many, many of the returns at the very top are what they call above-market rates of return, rents and so on,” a senior administration official told the Financial Times.

Coronavirus digest

  • India is to expand its vaccination programme to the over 18s but vaccine manufacturers will be allowed to raise prices significantly for scarce jabs. Medical supplies are being airlifted into the country to help battle a catastrophic second wave of Covid-19 infections, which experts is being undercounted.

  • Europe's largest banks plan to permanently slash business travel by as much as half from pre-pandemic levels after the crisis recedes. The chief executive of Qatar Airways warned of a need for co-operation on vaccine passports to save the aviation industry.

  • Vaccine makers have warned US officials that temporarily scrapping patents would risk handing novel technology to China and Russia.

  • US regulators have recommended healthcare providers resume using Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine after concluding the benefits outweighed the risks of serious blood clotting issues.

  • The battle over youth sports is just one aspect of a wider push by politicians and health officials to encourage Americans to remain cautious even as the US vaccine rollout continues at a rapid pace.

Sick of Zoom? So are climate scientists forced to meet online — except for them, much more is at stake, writes Pilita Clark. Follow the latest on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update email newsletter.

In the news

Chloé Zhao makes Oscar history The Chinese-American film-maker behind Nomadland has become the first woman of colour and the second woman to be named best director at the Academy Awards in Los Angeles. The awards marked a triumph for Walt Disney and the Hollywood establishment, as streaming company Netflix failed to clinch any of the big prizes.

Trump advisers flock back to Jones Day law firm Jones Day has welcomed back a slew of lawyers from the Trump administration since the start of the year, sealing the Midwestern firm's reputation as a central player in Republican party politics.

Exxon faces ‘existential' risk over fossil fuel focus The US energy company faces an “existential business risk” by pinning its future on fossil fuels as governments move to slash emissions, activist hedge fund and Exxon shareholder Engine No 1 will tell shareholders in an 80-page investor presentation seen by the Financial Times.

Credit Suisse shareholders seek removal of risk chief Some of Credit Suisse's largest shareholders will attempt to remove the board member in charge of risk oversight in protest at twin scandals that have cost the bank and its clients billions and tarnished its reputation.

Ukrainian leader calls for revamp of peace process In an interview with the Financial Times, Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelensky has called for a revamp of the 2015 accord intended to bring peace to the war-torn Donbas region with a bigger diplomatic role for the US, UK and Canada in ending the conflict.

  • A Joe Biden-Vladimir Putin summit could take place as early as June, a senior Kremlin official said on Sunday.

Supply chain snags Cargoes delayed by the grounding of a container ship in the Suez Canal this month are beginning to arrive at ports around the world, leaving hauliers rushing to catch up on the backlog. The deepening global chip crunch is spreading to makers of smartphones, televisions and home appliances, according to suppliers in Asia.

Biden calls Turkey's massacre of Armenians genocide Joe Biden described the first world war-era killing and deportation of as many as 1.5m Armenians as genocide over the weekend — breaking with decades of US precedent. Turkey warned Biden his words had “opened a wound” in relations between the two Nato allies. 

The day ahead

Earnings Canadian National Railway reports results on Monday as the board of Kansas City Southern reviews its proposed $33.7bn takeover offer. Electric carmaker Tesla also publishes results.

Economic data Data are expected to show demand for US durable goods rebounded in March after a weather-disrupted decline in February. (WSJ)

Italy's pandemic spending plans Prime Minister Mario Draghi will present plans to spend €190bn of EU loans and grants alongside a set of structural reforms. Sign-up to Europe Express — your essential guide to what matters in Europe today, every weekday morning.

Navalny organisation court hearing A closed court hearing is expected to uphold prosecutors' request to declare Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny's organisation “extremist” — which would cut off funding and could result in 10-year prison sentences for members.

What else we're reading

‘Drowning in insecurity': young people post-pandemic In the first of a new FT series, younger readers describe how they feel the social contract for their generation is broken. The editorials, to be published all week, will examine housing, pensions, jobs, education, climate and tax, and how they might be reformed to help the younger generation.

“If I carry on the way I am, I'm not sure what I'll be able to pass down,” Akin Ogundele, 34, says. “It can't be good for the country — the disparities are just going to grow, the wealthy are going to grow wealthier and those that aren't will get more and more removed.”

Sign up here to attend our FT Next Gen: A New Deal for the Young free webinar series this week.

There's no place like home — and the labour market needs to adjust What happens when people can't or won't move to where the jobs are? It's a question that American policymakers are focusing on in the wake of pandemic related job destruction, writes Rana Foroohar. “Longer term, it's quite clear that the nature of work is going to shift radically, with the possibility of many more jobs being done anywhere — be it Bangalore or Bangor,” she writes.

US activists look to ‘what comes next' after Chauvin murder verdict While activists welcomed the jury verdict in the Chauvin case, they say more work remains to be done at the federal, state and local level to address police violence and other issues of racial justice. “This is the beginning of an era that is going to bring about a lot of new changes, especially with closing the racial wealth gap,” says one activist.

Why ‘the kidnapping industry is thriving' in Nigeria Explosive population growth, rampant unemployment, underfunded and incapable security forces and easy access to small arms has made banditry a booming industry — and Nigeria's most serious security threat.

The pitfalls of open plan offices The parallel pressures of hybrid work, social distancing and post-pandemic efficiency measures have renewed the assault on executive floors. Chief executives enthuse about open-plan working — but staff tend to be less keen, caught between the perils of presenteeism and constant surveillance from a CEO panopticon.

Video of the day

Will zero emissions aviation take off? Aviation must find an alternative to fossil fuels if countries are to hit ambitious net zero targets by 2050. Peggy Hollinger looks at intriguing options using electric batteries, bio and synthetic fuels and hydrogen propulsion. Shipping, too, is looking to hydrogen as it seeks to ditch bunker fuel.
